key_points: The Suez Canal Authority announced a six percent increase in toll rates for most vessels in February 2022.
The toll increase follows a year of record traffic and comes despite the canal facing increased competition.
Admiral Osama Rabea, Chairman of the Suez Canal Authority, emphasized a balanced approach considering global economic conditions and competition.
LNG carriers and cruise ships are exempt from the toll increase to support these sectors.
The rate for LNG carriers is being modified from 25 percent to 15 percent.
Efforts are made to support the restoration of cruise ship traffic, affected by COVID-19.
The Suez Canal set a new record for transits in October with 1,847 transits and saw a 12 percent increase in revenues.
The highest daily transits recorded were on September 29, 2021, with 87 vessels.
During the first ten months of 2021, the canal saw a nearly nine percent increase in tonnage compared to the previous year.
The Authority is preparing for continued strong volumes and is upgrading its operations to enhance service.
spokespersons: Admiral Osama Rabea (Chairman, Suez Canal Authority)
